meta.title: Pak Constitution & Law MCQs - Historical Background
meta.description: Practice questions on the historical context and developments leading to the formation of Pakistan's Constitution.

questions.q: Which act of the British Parliament formally granted independence to British India and created Pakistan and India?
questions.ex: The Indian Independence Act 1947 implemented the partition plan and granted independence.

questions.q: Before the adoption of its own constitution, Pakistan was governed under a modified version of which act?
questions.ex: The Government of India Act 1935 served as the interim constitution until 1956.

questions.q: What resolution, passed in 1940, is considered a landmark in the struggle for a separate homeland for Muslims in British India?
questions.ex: The Lahore Resolution (also known as the Pakistan Resolution) called for independent states in Muslim-majority areas.

questions.q: Who is considered the founder of Pakistan?
questions.ex: Quaid-e-Azam Muhammad Ali Jinnah led the Pakistan Movement.

questions.q: When did Pakistan gain independence?
questions.ex: Pakistan's independence day is celebrated on August 14th.

questions.q: What was the name of the plan that proposed the partition of British India into India and Pakistan?
questions.ex: Lord Mountbatten, the last Viceroy of India, presented the plan for partition.

questions.q: Who was the first Prime Minister of Pakistan?
questions.ex: Liaquat Ali Khan played a crucial role in the early years of Pakistan.

questions.q: Who was the first Governor-General of Pakistan?
questions.ex: Quaid-e-Azam Muhammad Ali Jinnah held this position until his death.

questions.q: What was the major challenge faced by Pakistan immediately after independence in terms of constitution-making?
options: Disagreement on the role of Islam and representation
Border disputes with all neighboring countries
questions.ex: Reconciling different views on the nature of the state and ensuring fair representation for all regions were significant hurdles.

questions.q: What was the primary objective of the Constituent Assembly of Pakistan formed after independence?
options: To draft a constitution for the country
questions.ex: The Constituent Assembly's main task was to create a framework for governance.

questions.q: When was the first Constituent Assembly of Pakistan dissolved?
questions.ex: The dissolution of the first Constituent Assembly created a constitutional crisis.

questions.q: Who dissolved the first Constituent Assembly of Pakistan?
questions.ex: This action was controversial and challenged in the courts.

questions.q: What is the significance of the Objectives Resolution, passed in 1949?
options: It declared Pakistan an independent state
It laid down the fundamental principles for the future constitution of Pakistan
It established the federal structure of Pakistan
It defined the borders of Pakistan
questions.ex: The Objectives Resolution outlined the ideological basis for the constitution, emphasizing Islamic principles, democracy, and social justice.

questions.q: Who moved the Objectives Resolution in the Constituent Assembly?
questions.ex: Prime Minister Liaquat Ali Khan presented the Objectives Resolution.

questions.q: The inclusion of which principle in the Objectives Resolution was a point of debate?
questions.ex: The extent and interpretation of Islamic provisions in the constitution were widely discussed.

questions.q: What was the main reason for the delay in framing the first constitution of Pakistan?
options: Political instability and disagreements on constitutional issues
questions.ex: Frequent changes in government and lack of consensus on key constitutional matters prolonged the process.

questions.q: What was the One Unit scheme, introduced in 1955?
options: A plan to merge all princely states into Pakistan
A plan to combine the four provinces of West Pakistan into a single province
A plan to unite East and West Pakistan into a single province
A plan to establish a single political party
questions.ex: The One Unit scheme aimed to create parity between East and West Pakistan in the legislature, but it was controversial.

questions.q: What was the major demand from East Pakistan (now Bangladesh) regarding the constitution?
questions.ex: East Pakistan had a larger population than West Pakistan and sought representation proportional to its population.

questions.q: When was the first constitution of Pakistan finally adopted?
questions.ex: The 1956 Constitution was the first comprehensive constitution of Pakistan.

questions.q: What was the status of the Objectives Resolution in the 1956 Constitution?
options: It was included as a preamble
It was included as a part of Fundamental Rights
It was included as a Directive Principle of State Policy
questions.ex: The Objectives Resolution served as the guiding principles for the constitution.

questions.q: What form of government did the 1956 Constitution introduce?
questions.ex: The 1956 Constitution established a parliamentary system with a Prime Minister as the head of government.

questions.q: What was the official name of the country under the 1956 Constitution?
questions.ex: The 1956 Constitution declared Pakistan an Islamic Republic.

questions.q: What was the duration of the first Constituent Assembly of Pakistan?
questions.ex: The first Constituent Assembly was in existence from 1947 to 1954.

questions.q: Who was the President of the first Constituent Assembly of Pakistan?
questions.ex: Quaid-e-Azam Muhammad Ali Jinnah presided over the first Constituent Assembly until his death, after which Maulvi Tamizuddin Khan became the President.

questions.q: What is the significance of the Bogra Formula (1953)?
options: It proposed a solution to the language issue
It proposed a formula for representation in the legislature to break the constitutional deadlock
It proposed a plan for economic development
It proposed a system of local government
questions.ex: The Bogra Formula, proposed by Prime Minister Muhammad Ali Bogra, aimed to create parity between East and West Pakistan in both houses of the legislature.

questions.q: Which event led to the abrogation of the 1956 Constitution?
options: Passing of a new constitutional amendment
questions.ex: General Ayub Khan imposed Martial Law in 1958 and abrogated the constitution.

questions.q: What was the main characteristic of the political system under the modified Government of India Act 1935?
options: Parliamentary system with a weak center
questions.ex: The 1935 Act provided for a parliamentary system at the center and in the provinces.

questions.q: The inclusion of fundamental rights in the future constitution was emphasized in which document?
questions.ex: The Objectives Resolution listed fundamental rights as a key principle.

questions.q: What was the status of princely states after the partition of India?
options: They automatically became part of India
They automatically became part of Pakistan
They were given the choice to accede to either India or Pakistan or remain independent
They were put under direct British rule
questions.ex: The rulers of princely states had the option to join either dominion or remain independent, leading to complex accession issues.

questions.q: Which act defined the boundaries of the provinces of East Bengal and West Punjab after the partition?
questions.ex: The Radcliffe Award, headed by Sir Cyril Radcliffe, demarcated the boundaries between India and Pakistan.

questions.q: When was the Objectives Resolution passed by the Constituent Assembly of Pakistan?
questions.ex: The Objectives Resolution was adopted on March 12, 1949.

questions.q: Who moved the Objectives Resolution in the Constituent Assembly?
questions.ex: Prime Minister Liaquat Ali Khan presented the resolution.

questions.q: What is the significance of the Objectives Resolution in the constitutional history of Pakistan?
options: It was the first constitution of Pakistan
It laid down the foundational principles for the future constitution
questions.ex: The Objectives Resolution served as a roadmap and ideological statement for constitution-making.

questions.q: Which of the following is a key principle enshrined in the Objectives Resolution?
questions.ex: The resolution stated that sovereignty over the entire universe belongs to Almighty Allah alone.

questions.q: The Objectives Resolution stated that the State shall exercise its powers and authority through the chosen representatives of the people within the limits prescribed by:
questions.ex: This clause aimed to reconcile Islamic principles with democratic governance.

questions.q: The Objectives Resolution pledged that the principles of democracy, freedom, equality, tolerance, and social justice, as enunciated by Islam, would be fully observed. This reflects the emphasis on:
questions.ex: The resolution sought to integrate Islamic values into the political and social system.

questions.q: The Objectives Resolution guaranteed fundamental rights to all citizens, including equality of status, of opportunity and before law, social, economic and political justice, and freedom of thought, expression, belief, faith, worship and association, subject to:
options: The requirements of the ruling party
questions.ex: Fundamental rights were guaranteed within the framework of law and morality.

questions.q: The Objectives Resolution aimed to establish a political system based on which type of structure?
questions.ex: The resolution envisioned a federation with autonomous units.

questions.q: The Objectives Resolution emphasized the independence of which branch of government?
questions.ex: An independent judiciary was seen as essential for upholding the rule of law and protecting fundamental rights.

questions.q: The Objectives Resolution recognized the rights of minorities to freely profess and practice their religions and develop their cultures. This demonstrates a commitment to:
questions.ex: Protection of minority rights was a key aspect of the resolution.

questions.q: The Objectives Resolution was incorporated into the subsequent constitutions of Pakistan. In which constitution was it made a part of the Preamble?
questions.ex: The 1956 Constitution included the Objectives Resolution in its Preamble.

questions.q: In the 1973 Constitution, the Objectives Resolution was made a substantive part of the Constitution through which amendment?
options: Objectives Resolution was part of the original 1973 Constitution
questions.ex: The Objectives Resolution was included in the Annex to the 1973 Constitution from its inception.

questions.q: What was the main criticism against the Objectives Resolution by some sections of society?
options: It did not emphasize democracy enough
It gave too much power to the provinces
Its emphasis on Islamic principles was seen as ambiguous or potentially discriminatory towards minorities
It did not guarantee fundamental rights
questions.ex: The interpretation and implementation of the Islamic provisions were a source of debate and concern.

questions.q: The Objectives Resolution stated that the independence of the judiciary shall be fully secured. This reflects the principle of:
questions.ex: An independent judiciary is a cornerstone of the rule of law.

questions.q: The Objectives Resolution aimed to promote which type of justice?
questions.ex: The resolution had a broad vision for a just society.

questions.q: The Objectives Resolution declared that the people of Pakistan would be enabled to order their lives in the individual and collective spheres in accordance with the teachings and requirements of:
questions.ex: This clause explicitly linked the future constitution to Islamic principles.

questions.q: The Objectives Resolution is considered a foundational document for Pakistan's constitution-making process because:
options: It was the first law passed by the Constituent Assembly
It outlined the aspirations and guiding principles for the new state
It established the government structure immediately
It was the only document discussed by the Constituent Assembly
questions.ex: It provided a framework for the subsequent constitutional debates and drafting.

questions.q: The Objectives Resolution emphasized that the State shall safeguard the legitimate interests of minorities and backward and depressed classes. This highlights the commitment to:
questions.ex: The resolution aimed to ensure justice and equality for all sections of society.

questions.q: The Objectives Resolution was a major step towards defining the which nature of the Pakistani state?
questions.ex: The resolution sought to blend Islamic principles with democratic governance.

questions.q: Which part of the Objectives Resolution is related to the distribution of powers between the center and the provinces?
questions.ex: The resolution envisioned a federation with considerable autonomy for the constituent units.

questions.q: The Objectives Resolution stated that the territories now included in or accession to Pakistan and such other territories as may hereafter be included in Pakistan shall form a Federation wherein the Units will be:
questions.ex: The emphasis on autonomous units reflected the demand for provincial rights, particularly from East Pakistan.

questions.q: The Objectives Resolution's inclusion of Islamic principles was intended to reflect:
options: The aspirations of the majority Muslim population to build a state based on Islamic values
The adoption of a theocratic system
questions.ex: It aimed to align the state's framework with the religious identity and aspirations of the majority.

questions.q: The Objectives Resolution has been described as the 'Magna Carta' of Pakistan. This suggests its importance as:
options: A fundamental charter outlining key rights and principles
A document that limited the powers of the people
questions.ex: The term 'Magna Carta' is often used to denote a document of fundamental importance for constitutional development.

questions.q: The Objectives Resolution emphasized that the State shall make adequate provision for the people of Pakistan to develop themselves in accordance with the teachings and requirements of Islam and to observe their religious practices freely. This relates to:
questions.ex: The resolution linked individual and collective life to Islamic principles and guaranteed freedom of religious practice.

questions.q: The Objectives Resolution was a product of debates and discussions in which body?
questions.ex: The Constituent Assembly was responsible for framing the constitution.

questions.q: The Objectives Resolution stated that the integrity of the territories of the Federation, its independence and all its rights including its sovereign rights on land, sea and air shall be safeguarded. This relates to:
questions.ex: The resolution emphasized the importance of national sovereignty and territorial integrity.

questions.q: The Objectives Resolution's emphasis on social justice aligns with which broader goal?
questions.ex: Social justice aims to ensure fairness and equality in society.

questions.q: The Objectives Resolution stated that the head of the State would be a Muslim. This provision was later incorporated into the subsequent constitutions. This reflects the influence of which principle?
questions.ex: This provision is a clear reflection of the Islamic character envisioned for the state.

questions.q: The Objectives Resolution provided a framework for balancing which two concepts in the constitution?
questions.ex: The resolution aimed to create a federal system with a balance of power.

questions.q: The Objectives Resolution was passed during the tenure of which Governor-General?
questions.ex: Khawaja Nazimuddin became Governor-General after the death of Quaid-e-Azam.

questions.q: Which document laid the groundwork for incorporating Islamic provisions in the future constitution of Pakistan?
questions.ex: The Objectives Resolution explicitly stated that the principles of democracy, freedom, equality, tolerance, and social justice, as enunciated by Islam, would be fully observed.

questions.q: What is the official name of Pakistan as stated in the 1956, 1962 (later amended), and 1973 Constitutions?
questions.ex: The name 'Islamic Republic of Pakistan' reflects the state's ideological orientation.

questions.q: The Constitution of Pakistan declares that Islam shall be the state religion. This provision is found in which Constitution?
questions.ex: Article 2 of the 1973 Constitution declares Islam as the state religion.

questions.q: The Preamble of the Constitution of Pakistan affirms that sovereignty over the entire universe belongs to:
questions.ex: This is a direct reflection of the Objectives Resolution.

questions.q: According to the Constitution, the State shall enable the Muslims of Pakistan to order their lives in accordance with the principles of Islam as set out in the:
options: Teachings and requirements of the Holy Quran and Sunnah
questions.ex: The Quran and Sunnah are recognized as the primary sources of Islamic guidance.

questions.q: The Constitution includes provisions aimed at bringing existing laws into conformity with the injunctions of Islam. This is a key objective of the:
questions.ex: The Council of Islamic Ideology (CII) is a constitutional body tasked with advising the legislature on Islamic matters.

questions.q: What is the role of the Council of Islamic Ideology (CII)?
options: To interpret the Quran and Sunnah for individuals
To make recommendations to Parliament and Provincial Assemblies on how to bring laws into conformity with Islam
questions.ex: The CII's role is advisory.

questions.q: The Constitution includes a provision that no law shall be enacted which is repugnant to the injunctions of Islam as laid down in the Holy Quran and Sunnah. This is known as the:
questions.ex: This clause provides a legal framework for ensuring laws are consistent with Islamic principles.

questions.q: Which court in Pakistan has the power to examine and decide whether any law or provision of law is repugnant to the injunctions of Islam?
questions.ex: The Federal Shariat Court was established specifically for this purpose.

questions.q: The President of Pakistan must be a Muslim according to the Constitution. This provision reflects the influence of which document?
questions.ex: The Objectives Resolution included this requirement.

questions.q: The Constitution includes provisions to promote Islamic education. This is an example of:
questions.ex: The state is mandated to take steps to promote Islamic teachings.

questions.q: The Constitution emphasizes the importance of social justice as enunciated by Islam. This includes provisions related to:
options: Ensuring equality and fairness in society
Ignoring the needs of the poor
questions.ex: Islamic principles of social justice advocate for equitable distribution of resources and opportunities.

questions.q: The Constitution mentions the establishment of a Zakat and Ushr system. These are Islamic concepts related to:
questions.ex: Zakat is a mandatory charitable contribution, and Ushr is a tax on agricultural produce.

questions.q: The Constitution includes provisions for the protection of minorities' rights in accordance with Islam. This highlights the principle of:
questions.ex: Islam grants protection and rights to religious minorities.

questions.q: The 1973 Constitution specifies that the Chairman and members of the Council of Islamic Ideology must be persons who have considerable knowledge of:
questions.ex: Expertise in Islamic teachings is required for membership in the CII.

questions.q: The Federal Shariat Court's original jurisdiction is primarily concerned with:
options: Examining laws for repugnancy to Islam
questions.ex: This court's main role is to ensure laws are in line with Islamic injunctions.

questions.q: What is the relationship between the Federal Shariat Court and the Supreme Court of Pakistan?
options: The Federal Shariat Court is superior to the Supreme Court
Appeals from the Federal Shariat Court lie to the Shariat Appellate Bench of the Supreme Court
They are independent courts with no connection
The Supreme Court can overrule any decision of the Federal Shariat Court
questions.ex: The Shariat Appellate Bench of the Supreme Court is the final authority on matters of Islamic law.

questions.q: The Constitution includes provisions aimed at discouraging un-Islamic practices like Riba (usury or interest). This reflects the intention to establish an economic system based on:
questions.ex: Islamic economic principles prohibit interest-based transactions.

questions.q: The Islamic provisions in the Constitution are interpreted based on the injunctions of:
questions.ex: The Quran and Sunnah are the fundamental sources for interpreting Islamic principles in the Constitution.

questions.q: The Constitution emphasizes the importance of promoting moral standards in accordance with Islam. This relates to:
questions.ex: The state is mandated to take steps to promote Islamic values and ethics.

questions.q: The Islamic provisions in the Constitution are a reflection of:
options: The demands of a minority group
The historical background and ideological basis for the creation of Pakistan
questions.ex: The movement for Pakistan was rooted in the desire to establish a state where Muslims could live according to their faith.

questions.q: The Constitution includes provisions for the proper organization of Zakat, Ushr, Auqaf (religious endowments), and Mosques. This is aimed at:
options: Promoting and facilitating Islamic practices and institutions
questions.ex: The state takes responsibility for the proper functioning of these Islamic institutions.

questions.q: The Federal Shariat Court consists of Muslim Judges, including Ulema who are experts in Islamic Law. This composition is to ensure:
questions.ex: The inclusion of Ulema ensures that the court has the necessary knowledge of Islamic law to make its judgments.

questions.q: What is the primary challenge in the implementation of Islamic provisions in the Constitution?
options: Differing interpretations of Islamic law and reconciling them with modern legal requirements
questions.ex: Finding a balance between traditional Islamic interpretations and contemporary legal needs is an ongoing challenge.

questions.q: The Constitution includes a directive principle of State policy to bring the existing laws into conformity with the injunctions of Islam. This is a goal to be achieved:
options: Immediately after the constitution is adopted
Over time, through a gradual process
Only if the government decides to
Only if there is a public demand
questions.ex: This is a long-term objective requiring continuous effort and reform.

questions.q: The Islamic provisions in the Constitution are intended to serve as a guide for:
options: The state and its organs in all spheres of life
questions.ex: The state is expected to align its policies and laws with Islamic principles.

questions.q: The Federal Shariat Court can suo motu (on its own motion) examine any law to determine if it is repugnant to Islam. This indicates the court's role as a:
questions.ex: The court has the authority to initiate proceedings to review laws.

questions.q: Decisions of the Federal Shariat Court on whether a law is repugnant to Islam are binding on:
options: High Courts and other subordinate courts
Only the Council of Islamic Ideology
questions.ex: High Courts and lower courts must follow the rulings of the Federal Shariat Court on matters of Islamic law.

questions.q: The Constitution ensures that religious minorities have the right to practice their own religions and maintain their institutions. This is an example of:
options: Protecting religious freedom and diversity within an Islamic framework
questions.ex: The Constitution seeks to balance the state religion with the rights of minority communities.

questions.q: The inclusion of Islamic provisions in the Constitution of Pakistan is a reflection of which historical movement?
questions.ex: The Pakistan Movement was rooted in the desire of Muslims in British India to have a separate homeland where they could practice their faith freely.

questions.q: When was the first Constitution of Pakistan promulgated?
questions.ex: The 1956 Constitution was enacted on March 23, 1956.

questions.q: What form of government did the 1956 Constitution establish?
questions.ex: The constitution adopted a parliamentary system with a Prime Minister as the head of government and a President as the Head of State.

questions.q: What was the official name of the country under the 1956 Constitution?
questions.ex: This name reflected the influence of the Objectives Resolution.

questions.q: The 1956 Constitution provided for a federal system. How were powers divided between the center and the provinces?
options: All powers were with the center
All powers were with the provinces
Powers were divided into Federal, Provincial, and Concurrent lists
The constitution was unitary, not federal
questions.ex: The division of powers aimed to balance the authority of the central government and the provinces.

questions.q: What type of legislature did the 1956 Constitution introduce?
questions.ex: The legislature consisted of a single house, the National Assembly.

questions.q: How was representation in the National Assembly (under the 1956 Constitution) divided between East and West Pakistan?
questions.ex: The principle of parity gave equal seats to East and West Pakistan, despite East Pakistan's larger population, which was a point of contention.

questions.q: What was the role of the President under the 1956 Constitution?
questions.ex: The President was the ceremonial head of state, while the Prime Minister held executive authority.

questions.q: What was the role of the Prime Minister under the 1956 Constitution?
options: Chief Justice of the Supreme Court
questions.ex: The Prime Minister was the chief executive and led the cabinet.

questions.q: The 1956 Constitution incorporated the Objectives Resolution as its:
questions.ex: The Objectives Resolution served as the guiding principles for the constitution.

questions.q: Did the 1956 Constitution include a list of Fundamental Rights?
questions.ex: The constitution guaranteed fundamental rights to all citizens.

questions.q: What was the minimum age for a citizen to be eligible to vote under the 1956 Constitution?
questions.ex: The voting age was set at 21.

questions.q: How could the 1956 Constitution be amended?
options: By a simple majority in the National Assembly
By a two-thirds majority in the National Assembly
questions.ex: A supermajority was required for constitutional amendments.

questions.q: What was the duration of the National Assembly under the 1956 Constitution?
questions.ex: The term of the National Assembly was five years.

questions.q: What was the official language(s) of Pakistan under the 1956 Constitution?
questions.ex: Both Urdu and Bengali were recognized as official languages.

questions.q: What is the significance of the declaration that Pakistan is an Islamic Republic in the 1956 Constitution?
options: It meant all laws would be based strictly on Sharia immediately
It reflected the aspiration to align the state's framework with Islamic principles
questions.ex: The intention was to create a state guided by Islamic values while maintaining a democratic framework.

questions.q: Which institution was envisioned in the 1956 Constitution to advise on the Islamization of laws?
questions.ex: The Council of Islamic Ideology was established to provide recommendations on bringing laws into conformity with Islam.

questions.q: What event led to the abrogation of the 1956 Constitution?
options: A military coup led by General Ayub Khan
Passing of a vote of no confidence against the government
questions.ex: General Ayub Khan's imposition of Martial Law in October 1958 ended the first constitutional era.

questions.q: How long did the 1956 Constitution remain in effect?
questions.ex: The 1956 Constitution was in force for approximately two and a half years.

questions.q: Who was the President of Pakistan when the 1956 Constitution was promulgated?
questions.ex: Iskander Mirza became the first President of Pakistan under the 1956 Constitution.

questions.q: The failure to hold timely general elections under the 1956 Constitution contributed to:
questions.ex: The delay in holding elections undermined the democratic process and led to political crises.

questions.q: The 1956 Constitution aimed to address the issue of provincial autonomy by:
options: Dividing powers into three lists (Federal, Provincial, Concurrent)
Concentrating all powers at the center
questions.ex: The distribution of legislative powers was an attempt to provide autonomy to the provinces.

questions.q: What was the status of the judiciary under the 1956 Constitution?
options: It was controlled by the executive
It could not interpret the constitution
It only dealt with criminal cases
questions.ex: The constitution provided for an independent judiciary with powers of judicial review.

questions.q: The principle of parity in representation in the National Assembly under the 1956 Constitution was criticized by:
questions.ex: East Pakistan, with its larger population, felt that equal representation was unfair and undermined their democratic rights.

questions.q: The 1956 Constitution provided for which head of state?
questions.ex: The country transitioned from a Dominion with a Governor-General representing the British Crown to a Republic with an elected President.

questions.q: The abrogation of the 1956 Constitution and the imposition of Martial Law in 1958 is considered a significant event in Pakistan's history because:
options: It marked the first direct military intervention in the country's political affairs
questions.ex: This event set a precedent for future military interventions in politics.

questions.q: The 1956 Constitution was influenced by which previous legislation?
questions.ex: Many features of the 1956 Constitution were adapted from the Government of India Act 1935.

questions.q: What was the main reason cited by General Ayub Khan for abrogating the 1956 Constitution?
questions.ex: Ayub Khan argued that the parliamentary system had failed and political chaos necessitated military intervention.

questions.q: The 1956 Constitution aimed to establish a balance between which two wings of the country?
questions.ex: The constitution attempted to address the political and economic disparities between East and West Pakistan.

questions.q: Which constitutional principle was a major source of disagreement during the framing of the 1956 Constitution?
options: Distribution of powers between the center and provinces (especially representation)
questions.ex: The representation of East and West Pakistan in the federal legislature was a highly debated issue.

questions.q: The abrogation of the 1956 Constitution interrupted the process of:
questions.ex: The imposition of Martial Law suspended democratic institutions and the constitutional process.

questions.q: When was the Constitution of 1962 promulgated in Pakistan?
questions.ex: The 1962 Constitution was introduced by General Ayub Khan.

questions.q: What form of government did the 1962 Constitution establish?
questions.ex: The constitution adopted a presidential system with a strong President as the Head of State and Head of Government.

questions.q: Who was the President of Pakistan under the 1962 Constitution?
questions.ex: General Ayub Khan, who had imposed Martial Law, became the first President under this constitution.

questions.q: The 1962 Constitution introduced a system of indirect elections known as:
questions.ex: The Basic Democracies system involved elected representatives at local levels who would then elect the President and members of the National and Provincial Assemblies.

questions.q: What type of legislature did the 1962 Constitution establish?
questions.ex: The legislature consisted of a single house, the National Assembly.

questions.q: How was representation in the National Assembly (under the 1962 Constitution) structured between East and West Pakistan?
questions.ex: The principle of parity was maintained from the 1956 Constitution.

questions.q: What was the term of office for the President under the 1962 Constitution?
questions.ex: The President was elected for a term of five years.

questions.q: Did the 1962 Constitution initially include a list of Fundamental Rights?
questions.ex: Initially, the constitution did not have a separate chapter on Fundamental Rights, but they were later added through an amendment.

questions.q: The 1962 Constitution provided for a federal system. What was a key characteristic of this federalism?
questions.ex: The presidential system and distribution of powers concentrated significant authority in the central government.

questions.q: What was the official name of the country initially under the 1962 Constitution?
questions.ex: The initial constitution omitted the word 'Islamic' from the country's name, which was later added through an amendment.

questions.q: What was the impact of the Basic Democracies system on political participation?
options: It significantly broadened direct political participation for the masses
It limited direct political participation to a small number of elected representatives
It abolished all forms of political participation
It only allowed the military to participate
questions.ex: The indirect electoral system was criticized for limiting the direct role of the general public in electing the head of state and legislators.

questions.q: The 1962 Constitution was seen by some as a means to consolidate the power of:
questions.ex: The presidential system with its strong executive was seen as reinforcing the authority of the military-led government.

questions.q: How could the 1962 Constitution be amended?
options: By a simple majority in the National Assembly
By a two-thirds majority of the total membership of the National Assembly
questions.ex: A supermajority was required for constitutional amendments.

questions.q: What was the duration of the National Assembly under the 1962 Constitution?
questions.ex: The term of the National Assembly was five years.

questions.q: The 1962 Constitution included provisions for the establishment of which institution to advise on Islamic matters?
questions.ex: The Advisory Council of Islamic Ideology played a similar role to the Council of Islamic Ideology in the 1956 and 1973 Constitutions.

questions.q: What significant change was made to the 1962 Constitution through the First Amendment?
options: Changing the form of government to parliamentary
Restoring the name 'Islamic Republic of Pakistan' and including Fundamental Rights
Increasing the powers of the President
questions.ex: The First Amendment addressed key criticisms by reintroducing the Islamic name and a list of fundamental rights.

questions.q: The 1962 Constitution faced significant opposition and criticism, particularly from:
options: Political leaders and the public, especially in East Pakistan
questions.ex: The indirect electoral system, strong presidential powers, and issues of representation fueled opposition.

questions.q: What event led to the abrogation of the 1962 Constitution?
options: Mass protests and political unrest leading to Ayub Khan's resignation
questions.ex: The agitation against Ayub Khan's regime in 1968-1969 led to his stepping down and handing power to General Yahya Khan, who imposed Martial Law and abrogated the constitution.

questions.q: How long did the 1962 Constitution remain in effect?
questions.ex: The 1962 Constitution was in force from 1962 to 1969.

questions.q: The 1962 Constitution concentrated significant powers in the hands of:
options: The Speaker of the National Assembly
questions.ex: The President was the dominant figure in the political system.

questions.q: What was the role of the Vice President under the 1962 Constitution (after the First Amendment)?
options: Presiding officer of the National Assembly
questions.ex: The position of Vice President was created through the First Amendment.

questions.q: The 1962 Constitution aimed to create a system that Ayub Khan believed would be more 'suitable' for Pakistan. This was largely based on his experiences and observations of:
questions.ex: The constitution reflected Ayub Khan's preference for a strong, centralized executive.

questions.q: The lack of direct elections for the President and National Assembly under the Basic Democracies system was a major cause of:
questions.ex: The indirect system was seen as undemocratic and lacking legitimacy.

questions.q: The 1962 Constitution maintained the principle of parity in representation, which continued to be a source of grievance for:
questions.ex: East Pakistan felt that parity did not reflect its majority population and political strength.

questions.q: The abrogation of the 1962 Constitution led to the imposition of Martial Law by:
questions.ex: General Yahya Khan took over power after Ayub Khan's resignation.

questions.q: The 1962 Constitution was based on the report of which commission?
questions.ex: The Constitution Commission, headed by Justice Muhammad Shahabuddin, prepared a report that influenced the drafting of the 1962 Constitution.

questions.q: What was the initial official language under the 1962 Constitution?
questions.ex: English and Urdu were initially the official languages, but Bengali was later included as a national language through an amendment.

questions.q: The 1962 Constitution concentrated financial powers in the hands of:
questions.ex: The President had significant control over the national budget and financial matters.

questions.q: The 1962 Constitution was seen by its proponents as providing:
questions.ex: Supporters argued that a presidential system was better suited to address Pakistan's challenges and provide stable governance.

questions.q: The abrogation of the 1962 Constitution and the subsequent political developments ultimately led to:
options: The secession of East Pakistan and the creation of Bangladesh
A return to the parliamentary system
questions.ex: The political crisis under the 1962 Constitution and the events of 1971 led to the breakup of Pakistan.

questions.q: When was the current Constitution of Pakistan promulgated?
questions.ex: The 1973 Constitution was adopted on April 12, 1973, and came into effect on August 14, 1973.

questions.q: What form of government does the 1973 Constitution establish?
questions.ex: The constitution establishes a parliamentary system with the Prime Minister as the head of government.

questions.q: What is the official name of the country under the 1973 Constitution?
questions.ex: The name 'Islamic Republic of Pakistan' was retained from the 1956 Constitution.

questions.q: The 1973 Constitution provides for a federal system. How are legislative powers divided?
options: All powers are with the center
All powers are with the provinces
Powers are divided into Federal Legislative List and Concurrent Legislative List (though the Concurrent List has been abolished)
questions.ex: The Federal Legislative List enumerates subjects on which the federal Parliament can legislate, and the Concurrent List (now abolished after the 18th Amendment) allowed both federal and provincial legislatures to make laws.

questions.q: What type of legislature does the 1973 Constitution establish?
questions.ex: The Parliament consists of the National Assembly (lower house) and the Senate (upper house).

questions.q: What is the lower house of the Parliament of Pakistan called?
questions.ex: Members of the National Assembly are directly elected by the people.

questions.q: What is the upper house of the Parliament of Pakistan called?
questions.ex: The Senate provides equal representation to the provinces.

questions.q: What is the role of the President under the 1973 Constitution?
questions.ex: The President is the ceremonial head of state and acts on the advice of the Prime Minister.

questions.q: What is the role of the Prime Minister under the 1973 Constitution?
options: Chief Justice of the Supreme Court
questions.ex: The Prime Minister is the chief executive and is accountable to the National Assembly.

questions.q: The 1973 Constitution incorporates the Objectives Resolution as a substantive part of the Constitution in which document?
questions.ex: The Objectives Resolution is placed in the Annex to the 1973 Constitution and is considered a part of the Constitution itself.

questions.q: The 1973 Constitution includes a comprehensive list of Fundamental Rights. Which chapter deals with Fundamental Rights?
questions.ex: Chapter 1 of Part II of the Constitution enumerates the fundamental rights guaranteed to citizens.

questions.q: The 1973 Constitution abolished the One Unit scheme. This restored the status of which entities?
options: The four provinces of West Pakistan
East and West Pakistan as separate entities
questions.ex: The four provinces of Punjab, Sindh, Balochistan, and Khyber Pakhtunkhwa were restored.

questions.q: How can the 1973 Constitution be amended?
options: By a simple majority in the National Assembly
By a two-thirds majority of the total membership of both the National Assembly and the Senate
questions.ex: Constitutional amendments require a supermajority in both houses of Parliament.

questions.q: What is the term of office for the National Assembly under the 1973 Constitution?
questions.ex: The National Assembly is elected for a term of five years.

questions.q: What is the term of office for the Senate under the 1973 Constitution?
questions.ex: Senators are elected for a term of six years, with half retiring every three years.

questions.q: The 1973 Constitution established which institution to advise on the Islamization of laws?
questions.ex: The Council of Islamic Ideology's role is advisory.

questions.q: The 1973 Constitution created which court to examine laws for repugnancy to Islam?
questions.ex: The Federal Shariat Court was established in 1980 through a Presidential Order and later given constitutional status.

questions.q: The 1973 Constitution provides for the independence of the judiciary. This is enshrined in which part of the Constitution?
questions.ex: Chapter 1 of Part VII specifically deals with the Judicature.

questions.q: What is the minimum age for a citizen to be eligible to vote under the 1973 Constitution (after amendments)?
questions.ex: The voting age was reduced to 18 years.

questions.q: The 1973 Constitution declares Islam as the state religion. This is found in which article?
questions.ex: Article 2 establishes Islam as the state religion.

questions.q: The 1973 Constitution guarantees the rights of minorities to practice their religions freely. This is an example of:
questions.ex: The constitution provides safeguards for religious minorities.

questions.q: What is the Council of Common Interests (CCI)?
options: A body that advises the President
A forum for resolving disputes between the Federal Government and Provincial Governments
questions.ex: The CCI promotes coordination and resolves inter-provincial issues.

questions.q: The 1973 Constitution was unanimously passed by the National Assembly. This indicated:
options: Broad political consensus on its provisions
Imposition of the constitution by the government
questions.ex: The unanimous adoption reflected a national desire for a stable and inclusive constitutional framework after the events of 1971.

questions.q: Who was the Prime Minister of Pakistan when the 1973 Constitution was promulgated?
questions.ex: Zulfikar Ali Bhutto played a key role in the drafting and adoption of the 1973 Constitution.

questions.q: The 1973 Constitution restored the parliamentary system after a period of presidential rule under which constitution?
questions.ex: The 1973 Constitution marked a return to the parliamentary form of government.

questions.q: The 1973 Constitution is considered a living document because:
options: It can be amended over time to adapt to changing circumstances
It was drafted a long time ago
It is only relevant in theory
questions.ex: The ability to amend the constitution allows it to evolve with the needs of the country.

questions.q: The 18th Amendment to the 1973 Constitution made significant changes, including:
options: Strengthening provincial autonomy and parliamentary democracy
questions.ex: The 18th Amendment devolved more powers to the provinces and removed some of the powers of the President.

questions.q: The 1973 Constitution provides for a system of checks and balances between the different branches of government:
options: To concentrate power in one branch
To ensure that no one branch becomes too powerful
questions.ex: Checks and balances are essential for a functioning democracy.

questions.q: The 1973 Constitution is the longest-lasting constitution in Pakistan's history. This is often attributed to:
options: The political consensus around its formation and its ability to be amended
questions.ex: The broad-based support for the constitution and its adaptability have contributed to its longevity.

questions.q: The Preamble of the 1973 Constitution explicitly acknowledges the role of the Objectives Resolution. This confirms the Objectives Resolution's status as:
options: A guiding principle for the constitution
questions.ex: The Preamble recognizes the principles enshrined in the Objectives Resolution.

questions.q: Which amendment to the 1973 Constitution restored the name 'Islamic Republic of Pakistan' and included Fundamental Rights?
questions.ex: The First Amendment (1974) made these key changes to the interim constitution in effect before the permanent 1973 Constitution.

questions.q: Which amendment introduced the Preamble to the 1973 Constitution?
options: Preamble was part of the original constitution
questions.ex: The Preamble, which incorporates the Objectives Resolution, was part of the original 1973 Constitution.

questions.q: Which amendment validated the actions taken during the Martial Law period of General Zia-ul-Haq?
questions.ex: The Eighth Amendment (1985) introduced significant changes and validated actions taken by the military regime.

questions.q: The Eighth Amendment significantly increased the powers of which office?
questions.ex: The Eighth Amendment granted the President discretionary powers, including the power to dissolve the National Assembly.

questions.q: Which amendment is considered a landmark in strengthening provincial autonomy in Pakistan?
questions.ex: The Eighteenth Amendment (2010) devolved significant powers to the provinces, abolished the Concurrent Legislative List, and restored the parliamentary form of government to its original spirit.

questions.q: The 18th Amendment removed which power of the President?
options: Power to appoint the Prime Minister
Power to dissolve the National Assembly (Article 58(2)(b))
questions.ex: The controversial power to dissolve the National Assembly, introduced by the Eighth Amendment, was repealed by the Eighteenth Amendment.

questions.q: Which amendment restored the 1973 Constitution to its original form regarding the balance of power between the President and the Prime Minister, before the Eighth Amendment?
questions.ex: The Eighteenth Amendment aimed to bring the parliamentary system back to its original structure.

questions.q: Which amendment established military courts for the trial of civilians involved in terrorism-related offenses?
questions.ex: The Twenty-First Amendment (2015) was passed in the wake of the Peshawar school attack.

questions.q: Which amendment integrated the Federally Administered Tribal Areas (FATA) with Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province?
questions.ex: The Twenty-Fifth Amendment (2018) brought FATA into the constitutional and administrative fold of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa.

questions.q: The 13th Amendment (1997) is significant because it:
options: Increased the powers of the President
Removed the President's power to dissolve the National Assembly (Article 58(2)(b))
questions.ex: The Thirteenth Amendment initially curtailed the President's discretionary powers introduced by the Eighth Amendment, although some powers were later restored by the Seventeenth Amendment.

questions.q: Which amendment dealt with the composition of the Election Commission of Pakistan?
questions.ex: The Nineteenth Amendment (2010) addressed the appointment process for the Chief Election Commissioner and members of the Election Commission.

questions.q: The 20th Amendment (2012) focused on:
options: Composition of the National Finance Commission
Free and fair elections and caretaker governments
questions.ex: The Twentieth Amendment aimed to improve the electoral process and the appointment of caretaker governments.

questions.q: Which amendment is related to the delimitation of constituencies based on the 2017 census?
questions.ex: The Twenty-Sixth Amendment (2019) provided for the re-allocation of National Assembly seats based on the new census data.

questions.q: Which amendment was passed to extend the tenure of military courts established by the 21st Amendment?
questions.ex: The Twenty-Third Amendment (2017) extended the sunset clause for military courts.

questions.q: The 27th Amendment (2022) dealt with:
options: Increasing seats in the National Assembly for certain areas
questions.ex: The Twenty-Seventh Amendment increased the number of seats in the National Assembly for Balochistan and Khyber Pakhtunkhwa.

questions.q: Which amendment introduced the Legal Framework Order (LFO) of 2002 into the Constitution?
questions.ex: The Seventeenth Amendment (2003) validated actions taken by General Pervez Musharraf's regime and incorporated parts of the LFO into the Constitution.

questions.q: The 17th Amendment restored some of the discretionary powers of the President that had been removed by which amendment?
questions.ex: The 17th Amendment partially reversed the changes made by the 13th Amendment regarding the President's powers.

questions.q: Which amendment is related to the definition of a 'terrorist' for the purpose of military courts?
questions.ex: The 21st Amendment, which established military courts, also defined the scope of offenses to be tried by these courts.

questions.q: The 25th Amendment brought about significant administrative and political changes in which region?
questions.ex: The merger of FATA with Khyber Pakhtunkhwa was a major constitutional change.

questions.q: The 18th Amendment also changed the process for the appointment of judges to the superior courts. It introduced which body?
options: Parliamentary Committee on Appointment of Judges
questions.ex: The 18th Amendment established the Judicial Commission and a Parliamentary Committee for the appointment of judges.

questions.q: Which amendment is often referred to as the 'Charter of Democracy' amendment due to its emphasis on parliamentary supremacy and provincial autonomy?
questions.ex: The 18th Amendment was a significant step towards strengthening democratic institutions.

questions.q: The 24th Amendment (2017) was primarily concerned with:
options: Electoral reforms, including delimitation of constituencies
questions.ex: The 24th Amendment provided for the temporary reallocation of seats in the National Assembly and Provincial Assemblies based on the provisional results of the 2017 census.

questions.q: Which amendment is related to the right to free and compulsory education?
options: This right was in the original constitution
questions.ex: The 18th Amendment inserted Article 25A, making education a fundamental right.

questions.q: The 26th Amendment increased the number of seats in the National Assembly for which province?
questions.ex: This amendment aimed to address the representation needs of these provinces based on population growth.

questions.q: Which amendment is related to the establishment of the National Accountability Bureau (NAB)?
options: There is no amendment related to NAB in the Constitution
questions.ex: NAB was established through an Ordinance, not a constitutional amendment.

questions.q: The 18th Amendment also made changes to the distribution of financial resources between the federal government and the provinces. This is related to the:
questions.ex: The NFC Award determines the share of federal revenues allocated to the provinces.

questions.q: Which amendment dealt with the issue of floor crossing by members of Parliament?
questions.ex: The Fourteenth Amendment (1997) introduced provisions to prevent members of Parliament from changing their party affiliation.

questions.q: The 21st Amendment was challenged in the Supreme Court on the grounds of:
options: Violation of fundamental rights and judicial independence
questions.ex: The establishment of military courts and limitations on judicial review were key points of contention.

questions.q: Which amendment is related to the powers of the Senate?
options: Amendments generally affect both houses, but the 18th Amendment strengthened the Senate's role
questions.ex: The 18th Amendment increased the Senate's involvement in the legislative process and its oversight role.

questions.q: The process of amending the Constitution is designed to be challenging to ensure:
options: That the constitution is never changed
That amendments reflect broad political consensus and are not made arbitrarily
That only the ruling party can make changes
questions.ex: The requirement for a supermajority in both houses makes it difficult to amend the constitution without significant political agreement.

questions.q: Which part of the Constitution of Pakistan deals with Fundamental Rights?
questions.ex: Part II of the Constitution is dedicated to Fundamental Rights.

questions.q: What is a fundamental right?
options: A privilege granted by the government
A right that can be easily taken away
A basic right inherent to all human beings, guaranteed and protected by the Constitution
questions.ex: Fundamental rights are considered essential for individual liberty and dignity.

questions.q: Which article of the Constitution guarantees the right to life and liberty?
questions.ex: Article 9 states that no person shall be deprived of life or liberty save in accordance with law.

questions.q: The right to freedom of speech and expression is guaranteed under which article of the Constitution?
questions.ex: Article 19 allows citizens to express their opinions, subject to reasonable restrictions imposed by law.

questions.q: Which article of the Constitution ensures equality of citizens?
questions.ex: Article 25 states that all citizens are equal before the law and are entitled to equal protection of the law.

questions.q: The right to assemble peacefully and without arms is a fundamental right guaranteed under which article?
questions.ex: Article 16 allows citizens to gather for peaceful purposes.

questions.q: Which article guarantees the right to freedom of association and the right to form unions or associations?
questions.ex: Article 17 protects the right to form associations and unions, subject to reasonable restrictions imposed by law.

questions.q: The right to freedom of trade, business, or profession is guaranteed under which article?
questions.ex: Article 18 ensures the right to engage in any lawful profession or trade.

questions.q: Which article guarantees the right to acquire, hold, and dispose of property?
questions.ex: Article 23 protects property rights, subject to law.

questions.q: Which article, inserted by the 18th Amendment, made education a fundamental right?
questions.ex: Article 25A states that the State shall provide free and compulsory education to all children of the age of five to sixteen years.

questions.q: The right to dignity of man and, subject to law, the privacy of home, is guaranteed under which article?
questions.ex: Article 14 protects the dignity of individuals and the privacy of their homes.

questions.q: Which article guarantees the right to freedom of movement and residence?
questions.ex: Article 15 allows citizens to move freely throughout Pakistan and reside in any part of it.

questions.q: The right to access to information is a fundamental right under which article (after amendments)?
questions.ex: Article 19A, inserted by the 18th Amendment, guarantees the right to information, subject to regulation and reasonable restrictions imposed by law.

questions.q: Which article protects against double punishment (being tried and punished for the same offense twice)?
questions.ex: Article 13 provides protection against double punishment and self-incrimination.

questions.q: Which article prohibits slavery, forced labor, and child labor?
questions.ex: Article 11 aims to prevent exploitation and ensure freedom from involuntary servitude.

questions.q: The Constitution also outlines certain duties of citizens. Which of the following is a duty mentioned in the Constitution?
options: To disobey laws they disagree with
questions.ex: Paying taxes is a civic duty that contributes to the functioning of the state.

questions.q: Which article guarantees the right to freedom of religion?
questions.ex: Article 20 protects the right of every citizen to profess, practice, and propagate his religion.

questions.q: The Constitution ensures that no person shall be compelled to pay any special tax the proceeds of which are to be spent for the propagation or maintenance of any religion other than his own. This is related to:
questions.ex: This provision protects individuals from being forced to support religions they do not belong to.

questions.q: The right to preserve and promote distinct language, script, or culture is guaranteed for citizens having such distinct identity under which article?
questions.ex: Article 28 protects the cultural rights of minorities and distinct groups.

questions.q: The Fundamental Rights in the Constitution are enforceable by which body?
options: The Judiciary (High Courts and Supreme Court)
questions.ex: Citizens can approach the High Courts or the Supreme Court to seek enforcement of their fundamental rights.

questions.q: Which constitutional remedy allows a person to challenge their unlawful detention?
questions.ex: Habeas Corpus is a writ requiring a person under arrest to be brought before a judge or into court.

questions.q: Which writ is issued by a higher court to a lower court to stop it from exceeding its jurisdiction?
questions.ex: Prohibition prevents a court from acting outside its legal authority.

questions.q: Which writ is issued by a higher court to a lower court to quash (set aside) an order made in excess of jurisdiction or in violation of natural justice?
questions.ex: Certiorari reviews the legality of proceedings in a lower court.

questions.q: Which writ is a judicial remedy in the form of an order from a superior court, to any government subordinate court, corporation, or public authority, to do some specific act which appertains to their official duty?
questions.ex: Mandamus compels a public authority to perform a legal duty.

questions.q: Which writ is used to inquire into the authority by which a public officer holds office?
questions.ex: Quo Warranto challenges the legal right of a person to hold a public office.

questions.q: The principle of 'No person shall be deprived of life or liberty save in accordance with law' reflects the concept of:
questions.ex: The rule of law requires that all actions are taken according to established legal procedures.

questions.q: Which Fundamental Right is related to safeguards as to arrest and detention?
questions.ex: Article 10 provides rights to arrested persons, including the right to be informed of the grounds for arrest and the right to legal counsel.

questions.q: Which Fundamental Right is related to the prevention of retrospective punishment?
questions.ex: Article 12 protects individuals from being punished for an act that was not an offense when it was committed.

questions.q: The Constitution outlines certain Principles of Policy, which are:
options: Directives for the State to be guided by in policy making
questions.ex: Principles of Policy are not enforceable by courts but are considered fundamental to the governance of the State.

questions.q: While Fundamental Rights are enforceable in courts, the Principles of Policy are:
options: Not enforceable in courts, but are guiding principles
Optional for the government to follow
questions.ex: This is a key distinction between Fundamental Rights and Principles of Policy.

questions.q: Which part of the Constitution of Pakistan deals with Principles of Policy?
questions.ex: Part III of the Constitution outlines the Principles of Policy.

questions.q: Are the Principles of Policy enforceable in any court?
options: Only if the Parliament makes a law to enforce them
questions.ex: Principles of Policy are non-justiciable, meaning they cannot be enforced through court action.

questions.q: What is the purpose of the Principles of Policy?
options: To define the structure of the government
To provide guidelines for the State in policy making
To list the duties of citizens
questions.ex: These principles are intended to guide the State in achieving its social, economic, and political objectives.

questions.q: One of the Principles of Policy is to enable the Muslims of Pakistan to order their lives in accordance with the principles of Islam. This reflects the influence of:
questions.ex: This principle reiterates a key objective from the Objectives Resolution.

questions.q: A Principle of Policy is to discourage parochial, racial, tribal, sectarian, and provincial prejudices among the citizens. This promotes:
questions.ex: The State is encouraged to work towards a cohesive and harmonious society.

questions.q: A Principle of Policy is to promote social and economic well-being of the people. This includes directives related to:
options: Reducing poverty and providing basic necessities
Concentrating wealth in a few hands
Limiting access to healthcare and education
questions.ex: The State is guided to work for the welfare of its citizens.

questions.q: A Principle of Policy is to ensure the participation of women in all spheres of national life. This aims to promote:
questions.ex: The State is encouraged to take measures to empower women.

questions.q: A Principle of Policy is to protect the family, marriage, mother and child. This highlights the importance of:
questions.ex: The State is guided to support and strengthen the family unit.

questions.q: A Principle of Policy is to ensure the elimination of illiteracy and provision of free and compulsory secondary education. This reflects a commitment to:
questions.ex: While Article 25A makes education a fundamental right, the Principles of Policy reiterate the State's commitment to educational development.

questions.q: A Principle of Policy is to make technical and professional education generally available and make higher education equally accessible to all on the basis of merit. This promotes:
options: Development of skilled workforce and equal opportunity
questions.ex: The State is encouraged to invest in education and provide equal opportunities.

questions.q: A Principle of Policy is to provide for all citizens within the resources available, facilities for work and adequate livelihood. This is related to:
options: Ignoring the needs of the workforce
questions.ex: The State is guided to work towards full employment and decent living standards.

questions.q: A Principle of Policy is to reduce disparity in the income and earnings of individuals. This aims to promote:
questions.ex: The State is encouraged to take measures to reduce the gap between the rich and the poor.

questions.q: A Principle of Policy is to provide social security by means of compulsory social insurance or otherwise for all persons employed in the public or private sector. This is related to:
options: Providing support in times of need
questions.ex: The State is guided to establish systems that protect individuals from economic hardship.

questions.q: A Principle of Policy is to ensure that the bonds with the Muslim world are preserved and strengthened and to promote international peace and security. This relates to:
questions.ex: The State is guided to foster good relations with other Muslim countries and contribute to global peace.

questions.q: A Principle of Policy is to protect against the exploitation of children and women. This aims to ensure:
questions.ex: The State is encouraged to take measures to prevent the abuse and exploitation of vulnerable groups.

questions.q: A Principle of Policy is to preserve the sanctity of the family and to promote Islamic moral standards. This relates to:
questions.ex: The State is guided to uphold moral values and protect the institution of family.

questions.q: A Principle of Policy is to make provisions for securing just and humane conditions of work. This is related to:
questions.ex: The State is encouraged to ensure fair treatment and safe working conditions for all employees.

questions.q: A Principle of Policy is to protect the legitimate rights and interests of minorities. This reinforces the commitment to:
options: Inclusivity and equality for all citizens
questions.ex: The State is guided to safeguard the rights of minority communities.

questions.q: A Principle of Policy is to encourage local government institutions. This promotes:
options: Decentralization of power and community participation
questions.ex: The State is encouraged to empower local communities through effective local governance.

questions.q: A Principle of Policy is to protect the environment and biodiversity. This reflects a commitment to:
questions.ex: The State is guided to take measures to protect the natural environment and its resources.

questions.q: While not legally enforceable, the Principles of Policy serve as a guide for which branches of government?
questions.ex: All branches of government are expected to be guided by these principles in their actions and decisions.

questions.q: A Principle of Policy is to promote the concept of 'Ummah' and friendly relations among Muslim countries. This relates to:
options: Fostering unity and cooperation among Muslim nations
Aligning with non-Muslim countries against Muslim countries
questions.ex: The concept of Ummah emphasizes the global community of Muslims.

questions.q: A Principle of Policy is to provide for the basic necessities of life, such as food, clothing, housing, education, and medical relief, for all citizens. This is a broad directive related to:
options: Ensuring a minimum standard of living
questions.ex: The State is guided to work towards providing essential services to all its citizens.

questions.q: A Principle of Policy is to ensure that the citizens are aware of their rights and duties. This promotes:
questions.ex: An informed citizenry is essential for a functioning democracy.

questions.q: A Principle of Policy is to promote justice and fair play in the administration of law. This relates to:
questions.ex: The State is guided to ensure fairness and impartiality in the legal system.

questions.q: A Principle of Policy is to prevent the accumulation of wealth and means of production in the hands of a few. This aims to promote:
options: Equitable distribution of wealth and resources
questions.ex: The State is encouraged to take measures to prevent the concentration of economic power.

questions.q: A Principle of Policy is to ensure the decentralization of administration. This aims to improve:
options: Efficiency and accessibility of government services
questions.ex: Decentralization brings decision-making closer to the people.

questions.q: A Principle of Policy is to provide for adequate medical facilities and health care for all citizens. This is related to:
questions.ex: The State is guided to prioritize public health and well-being.

questions.q: A Principle of Policy is to safeguard the educational and cultural interests of minorities. This reinforces the commitment to:
questions.ex: The State is encouraged to support the cultural development of minority communities.

questions.q: The Principles of Policy serve as a link between which two parts of the Constitution?
options: Preamble and the rest of the Constitution
questions.ex: The Principles of Policy elaborate on the goals and aspirations outlined in the Preamble.

questions.q: What form of government does the Constitution of Pakistan establish?
questions.ex: Pakistan is a federation consisting of provinces and other territories.

questions.q: In a federal system, how is power typically divided?
options: All power is concentrated in the central government
All power is concentrated in the provincial governments
Power is divided between a central (federal) government and regional (provincial) governments
Power is held only by the judiciary
questions.ex: Federalism involves a division of authority between different levels of government.

questions.q: Which part of the Constitution of Pakistan deals with the Federation of Pakistan?
questions.ex: Part I of the Constitution outlines the basic features of the Federation.

questions.q: The legislative powers in Pakistan are divided between the Federal Parliament and the Provincial Assemblies. Which legislative list is under the exclusive domain of the Federal Parliament?
questions.ex: The Federal Legislative List includes subjects of national importance like defense, foreign affairs, and currency.

questions.q: Before the 18th Amendment, the Concurrent Legislative List contained subjects on which both the Federal Parliament and Provincial Assemblies could legislate. Which government's law would prevail in case of a conflict?
questions.ex: In case of a conflict, federal law would take precedence over provincial law on subjects in the Concurrent List.

questions.q: What happened to the Concurrent Legislative List after the 18th Amendment?
options: It was transferred to the Federal List
questions.ex: The abolition of the Concurrent List was a major step towards strengthening provincial autonomy.

questions.q: After the abolition of the Concurrent List, most of the subjects from this list were transferred to the domain of:
questions.ex: This transfer significantly increased the legislative and executive powers of the provinces.

questions.q: Which constitutional body is responsible for coordinating between the Federal Government and the Provincial Governments and resolving disputes?
questions.ex: The CCI plays a crucial role in inter-provincial harmony and coordination on matters of common interest.

questions.q: Who is the Chairman of the Council of Common Interests (CCI)?
questions.ex: The Prime Minister presides over the meetings of the CCI.

questions.q: What are the constituent units of the Federation of Pakistan?
options: Provinces and other territories (like Islamabad Capital Territory and FATA before merger)
questions.ex: Pakistan currently consists of four provinces, the Islamabad Capital Territory, and Gilgit-Baltistan and Azad Jammu and Kashmir (with special status).

questions.q: Each province in Pakistan has its own elected legislature called the:
questions.ex: Provincial Assemblies are responsible for legislating on matters within the provincial domain.

questions.q: Who is the head of the Provincial Government?
questions.ex: The Chief Minister is the chief executive of the province.

questions.q: Who is the representative of the Federal Government in the province?
questions.ex: The Governor is appointed by the President and acts as the constitutional head of the province.

questions.q: The distribution of financial resources between the Federal Government and the Provincial Governments is determined by the:
questions.ex: The NFC Award is a constitutional mechanism for the horizontal and vertical distribution of financial resources.

questions.q: The 18th Amendment significantly enhanced the financial autonomy of the provinces by increasing their share in the:
options: Federal Consolidated Fund (through the NFC Award)
questions.ex: The provinces received a larger share of the federal divisible pool after the 18th Amendment.

questions.q: Which article of the Constitution deals with the appointment of the Governor of a province?
questions.ex: Article 101 outlines the process of appointing the Governor.

questions.q: Which article of the Constitution deals with the appointment of the Chief Minister of a province?
questions.ex: Article 130 describes the procedure for the appointment of the Chief Minister.

questions.q: The Provincial Assembly elects the:
questions.ex: The Chief Minister is elected by the majority of the members of the Provincial Assembly.

questions.q: The role of the Senate in the Federal Parliament is to provide:
options: Equal representation to the federating units (provinces)
Representation only to the federal government
questions.ex: The Senate ensures that all provinces have an equal voice in the federal legislature.

questions.q: The Council of Common Interests (CCI) is an important constitutional body for:
questions.ex: The CCI provides a platform for dialogue and decision-making on matters affecting both the federal and provincial governments.

questions.q: What is the difference between a federal system and a unitary system?
options: In a federal system, all power is with the center; in a unitary system, power is divided
In a unitary system, all power is with the center; in a federal system, power is divided
A federal system has one level of government; a unitary system has multiple levels
A federal system has no written constitution; a unitary system does
questions.ex: The key distinction is the concentration versus division of power.

questions.q: The Constitution of Pakistan defines the territorial limits of the provinces. This is important for:
options: Establishing clear jurisdictions for federal and provincial governments
questions.ex: Defined boundaries are necessary for the effective functioning of a federal system.

questions.q: The relationship between the Federal Government and the Provincial Governments is governed by the principles of:
questions.ex: While there may be disagreements, the ideal is cooperation for the effective governance of the country.

questions.q: The 18th Amendment also made changes to which institution, giving provinces a greater say in its composition?
questions.ex: The representation of provinces in the NFC was strengthened.

questions.q: The Provinces have exclusive legislative competence on subjects not included in the Federal Legislative List (after the abolition of the Concurrent List). These are often referred to as:
questions.ex: Subjects within the provincial domain include areas like health, education (mostly), and agriculture.

questions.q: Which article of the Constitution deals with the legislative relations between the Federation and the Provinces?
questions.ex: Articles 141 to 144 outline the extent of federal and provincial laws and the distribution of legislative powers.

questions.q: The executive authority of a province is vested in:
options: The Chief Minister and the Provincial Cabinet
questions.ex: The Chief Minister, along with the cabinet, exercises executive authority in the province.

questions.q: The Federal Government can issue directives to the Provincial Governments in certain matters to ensure compliance with:
options: The policies of the ruling party
questions.ex: The Federal Government has the authority to ensure that provinces act in accordance with the Constitution and federal laws.

questions.q: The creation of new provinces in Pakistan would require a constitutional amendment. This highlights the significance of the Constitution in defining the:
options: Territorial integrity and structure of the federation
questions.ex: Changes to the number or boundaries of provinces require a formal amendment to the Constitution.

questions.q: The principle of provincial autonomy aims to empower provinces to make decisions on matters that primarily affect their:
questions.ex: Provincial autonomy allows provinces to address the specific needs and priorities of their populations.

subcategories.title: Role and Powers of the President

questions.q: What is the constitutional position of the President of Pakistan?
